captions.text: # The Law You Won't Be Told

On a Jury you know your options: guilty, or
not. But there's another choice that neither

the judge nor the lawyers will tell you -- often
because they're not allowed to and also it
might better if you *don't* know.

This video will tell you that third choice,
but be warned: simply *watching* may prevent

you from ever serving on a jury -- so this
is your last chance to hit the pause button
before you learn about...

Jury nullification: when the defendant is
100% beyond-a-reasonable-doubt guilty *but*

the jurors *also* think he shouldn't be punished.
The jury can nullify the law and let him go
free.

But before your on your next jury and yell
'Null! Booya!' at the judge you should know

that just talking about jury nullification
in the wrong circumstances can get you arrested.

Though a video such as this one, simply acknowledging
the *existence* of jury nullification and

in *no way advocating* it is totally OK. And,
while we're at it:

*(CGP Grey is not a lawyer, this is not legal
advice it is meant for entertainment purposes

only. Seriously, guy, don't do anything in
a court of law based on what an Internet Video
told you. No joke.)*

So why can't you do this? It's because nullification
isn't *in* the law †, but exists as a logical
consequence of two other laws:

First: that juries can't be punished for a
'wrong' decision -- no matter the witnesses,

DNA, or video proof show. That's the point
of a jury: to be the decider.
and

Second: when a defendant is found not-guilty,
that defendant can't be tried again for the
same crime ‡.

So there *are* only two stated options: guilty
or not, it's just that jury nullification

is when the words of the jurors don't match
their thoughts -- for which they can't be

punished and their not-guilty decision can't
be changed.

These laws are necessary for juries to exist
within a fair system, but the logical consequence

is... contentious -- lawyers and judges argue
about jury nullification like physicists argue

about quantum mechanics. Both are difficult
to observe and the interpretation of both

has a huge philosophical ramification for
the subject as a whole.

Is nullification the righteous will of the
people or an anarchy of twelve or just how
citizens judge their laws?

The go-to example in favor of nullification
is the fugitive slave law: when Northern juries

refused to convict escaped slaves and set
them free.
Can't argue with that.

But the anarchy side is Southern juries refusing
to convict white lynch mobs. Not humanity
at its best.

But both of these are juries nullifying the
law.

Also juries have *two* options where their
thoughts may differ from their words. Jury

nullification usually refers to the non-guilty
version but juries can convict without evidence

just as easily as they can acquit in spite
of it.

This is jury nullification too and the jurors
are protected by the first rule, though the

second doesn't apply and judges have the power
to overrule a guilty verdict if they think

the jurors are… nt the best. And, of course,
a guilty defendant can appeal, at least for

a little while. Which makes the guilty form
of jury nullification weaker than the not-guilty
kind. Cold comfort, though.

Given the possibility of jurors who might
ignore the law as written, it's not surprising

when picking jurors for a trial, lawyers -- whose
existence is dependent on an orderly society

-- will ask about nullification, usually in
the slightly roundabout way:

"Do you have any beliefs that might prevent
you from making a decision based strictly
on the law?"

If after learning about jury nullification
you think it's a good idea: answer 'yes' and

you'll be rejected, but answer 'no' with the
intent to get on the jury to nullify and you've

just committed perjury -- technically a federal
crime -- which makes the optimal strategy
once on a jury to zip it.

But This introduces a problem for jurors who
intend to nullify: telling the other 11 angry

men about your position is risky, which makes
nullification as a tool for fixing unjust
laws nation wide problematic.

(Not to mention about 95% of criminal charges
in the United States never make it to trial

and rather end in a plea bargain, but that's
a story for another time.)

The only question about jury nullification
that may matter is if jurors should be *told*

about it and the courts are near universal
† in their decision: 'no way'.

Which might seem self-interested -- again,
courts depend on the law -- but there's evidence

that telling jurors about nullification changes
the way they vote by making evidence less

relevant -- which isn't surprising: that's
what nullification *is*. But mock trials also

show sympathetic defendants get more non-guilty
verdicts and unsympathetic defendants get

more *guilty* verdicts in front of jurors
who were explicitly told about nullification
compared to those who weren't.

Which sounds bad, but it also isn't difficult
to imagine situations where jurors blindly

following the law would be terribly unjust
-- which is the heart of nullification: juries
judge the law, not solely evidence.

In the end righteous will of the people, or
anarchy, or citizen lawmaking -- the system

leaves you to decide -- but as long as courts
are fair they require these rules, so jury
nullification will always be with us.

title: The Law You Won't Be Told

:: Of course not, but what is wrong with suggesting that the channel

comments.author: mPky1

comments.text:
+mPky1
Wow, you are a piece of work. Let me break this one down to you.

There is nothing wrong with making videos about your own country or *any 
other subject matter that interests you*. For you to say that 
everyone/anyone needs to make videos about other countries, despite the 
fact that other countries do not interest them or aren't relevant to them, 
is far more ignorant than anything else in this entire conversation. Why 
does everyone need to know about your country? We does everyone need to 
know about my country? Simple answer- They don't.
However interesting other cultures may be, not everyone NEEDS to take 
interest in them and be forced feed facts that are completely irrelevant to 
their lives. You use insular as though its an insult, or a belittling 
statement, when its not.

Let me explain it to you this way. Its analogous to me liking cats and 
wanting to make a video about cats, however you say, "there are more 
animals in the world than just cats, you are ignorant for not taking 
interest in other animals and you should make videos about animals that are 
relevant to non-cat lovers."
While its true, there are other animals, and they probably are fascinating, 
you have literally no right or reason to force me or anyone to take 
interest in those animal. Ignoring those animals is not ignorance, its 
disinterest. Belittling people for the things they don't care about is pure 
bigotry.


Ultimately, why would a cat-lover ever make a video about another animal, 
just because other animals exist? Why would a person who's only interested 
in American laws, make a video about laws from other countries? The 
demographic of this video is Americans. You have to accept that you just 
aren't represented in this video. There are probably million of videos 
where you, your country, and your numerous interests ARE represented. 
Trying to get everyone to represent your interests just because your 
interests exist, is ridiculous and immature.

I respect that you want other people to expand their horizons and learn 
about other countries, but it would be completely ignorant of you to assume 
everyone should like and care about the same things you like and care 
about. It would be ignorant to assume that everyone needs to learn about 
other countries when I'm sure possibly hundred of millions of people are 
completely content, educated, well-rounded and cultured without ever 
knowing anything about anyone elses country aside from their own.

Maybe in your country people like to make content that doesn't interest 
them just so they can represent every single person that might come across 
their videos, but where I live people are allowed to do whatever they want. 
And I don't go around telling people they need to represent my country or 
else they are ignorant, because that would be ignorance in of itself.

And for the record. I watch plenty of videos about all sorts of countries. 
However, when I see ridiculous remarks, like your own, I'm compelled to 
show them just how illogical they sound.
comments.author: KellySmith555

comments.text:
+KellySmith555 > Why would a non-American be upset with an American for 
making videos about America? Simple answer- No justifiable reason whatsoever

:: You simply dont understand that this insular view makes you ignorant.

comments.author: mPky1

comments.text:
+mPky1
Why would non-Americans watch a video made by an American? Simple answer- 
because they can.
So you are free to watch whatever you want. Enjoy yourself.

Why would an American make a video about American laws or anything else for 
that matter? Simple answer- because they can.
So CGP is free to make whatever videos he wants and he doesn't have to 
cater to anyone besides himself.

Why would a non-American be upset with an American for making videos about 
America? Simple answer- No justifiable reason whatsoever.

I think you need to realize that the world doesn't cater to you and your 
country. The world doesn't cater to Americans either. If you have a problem 
with American-centric videos or channels, than you should find channels 
that are dedicated to things that pertain to you, rather than telling 
people they should make content that doesn't interest them just so they can 
make you happy.
comments.author: KellySmith555

comments.author: Esper Skel

comments.text:
Avoid Jury Duty when possible.  Some people see it as a duty, but really... 
Who are YOU to send someone 'down the river'.  If you are arrested and 
definitely NOT Guilty then get a Judge to hear your case.  If you are 
arrested and definitely GUILTY then get a Jury.  The prison system in the 
USA has become a real money maker and can't afford any empty beds (like a 
government owned hotel that can force you to spend a few years).  Jury 
Nullification is a fool's errand if you try it in a 21st century 
bureaucracy like the California Superior Court system.  Still an 
interesting vid!﻿
comments.author: randy109

comments.text:
Remember this:
Lawyers (both sides) do not want intelligent people on juries.  If the case 
is about a vehicular mechanical reason, they do not want mechanics on the 
jury.  If the case is about computers, they do not want any one with any 
knowledge about computers. 
Both sides fear an intelligent juror.  That is why you have Voir Dior - the 
right to remove any person (3x) for any reason.
They want jurors (so they can hold up a blue pen and say, "ladies and 
Gentlemen of the Jury, this is a green pen"  - the jurors then nod, "Yep, 
the pen is green.")
They also want obedient jurors.  Obedient Jurors never ask questions.  they 
never  do anything that the judge does not want to happen.﻿
comments.author: david giles

comments.text:
The whole idea of jury is unfortunate. I am happy that we do not have it in 
our legal system anymore. Honestly, who want to rely on a judgment of a 
bunch most likely unqualified people with no legal training whatsoever .... 
since I have no legal training, would definitely refuse to do it, since I 
do not feel qualified to do it as a political scientist.﻿

comments.text:
So double jeopardy is partly to blame for jury nullification?
I was introduce to both these ideas long ago by a movie called "How to 
Murder Your Wife.  To summarize: A henpecked husband's wife runs off and he 
is accused of her murder.  During the trial he claims he did kill her but 
asks that the jury, itself composed of henpecked husbands, find him 
innocent thus sending a message to the wives of America.  He later confides 
in a friend the he didn't kill his wife, she had probably just run back to 
her mother.  The friend tells him that should she return he can legally 
kill her since he can't be tried for the same murder twice.﻿

real and hypothetical murder would be a separate crime.

comments.author: Casey Callahan

comments.text:
I know about nullification and have served on juries, but haven't needed to 
exercise the right so far. I would if I felt the need to. The key as 
explained in this video is to not admit to knowing about nullification, 
deny knowledge of it if confronted, and if you want to convey the concept 
to other jurors, phrase your words in a way that doesn't use the actual 
term. Tell them that they should vote with their gut feeling and ignore 
instructions. That they cannot be convicted of voting the way the judge 
thinks they should vote, because really, why are we here? If they wanted 
robots they'd just have a computer program make the decision. But since we 
are human beings, we get to vote with our minds and conscience. ﻿
comments.author: dkeith45

comments.author: Danielle Lawson

comments.text:
A few more things to make the justice system better. A get rid of death as 
a punishment, B, a minimum age to be convicted for anything at 12, to be 
tried as an adult, 16, plus a functioning youth justice system. C, judges 
and prosecutors, and attorney generals are not elected positions but are 
chosen by experts. D, private prisons to cease to exist or will be handed 
over to the government, E, getting rid of the three strikes rule, F, there 
is a total time limit for how long a person may stay in a jail, which would 
be 4 months. There would be enough courts to handle this number of cases at 
once. G, jails are not like prisons, they are more for detaining a person 
who may be innocent, secure enough to prevent escape, but no more. Prisons 
also have more rehabilitation systems and punishment is not the main reason 
prisons exist. H, there are to be as few minimum sentences as possible, 
only for murders, aggravated assaults or robberies, and some other 
crimes. I, certain things are legalized, or at least decriminalized, and 
drug consumption and selling certain amounts is a health issue not a 
criminal one. IE, you do not go to prison for these crimes. J, the problems 
that lead to criminal behavior is removed. Alcoholism, drug use, poverty, 
and these social reasons. K, non-violent and violent offenders are 
separated from the start of incarceration and in jails waiting to go on 
trail. L, for most non-violent and some violent crimes with the end of 
sentence being a certain number of years ago, having a criminal record is 
not to be disclosed unless there is a real reason, like if working with 
children, or hospital patients, and in even more professions, having a 
record shall not discriminate, and benefits programs and governmental 
assistance shall not be hindered if one has a record. 

These ideas will dramatically reduce the poverty, overcrowding and number

comments.author: Lights Blade

comments.text:
Unfortunately, this video is misleading. Almost all criminal juries must be 
unanimous to convict or to acquit. If not, the jury is hung and the judge 
will declare a mistrial. The prosecutor is free to bring charges again for 
a mistrial. Jury nullification only happens when the ENTIRE jury decides to 
acquit (or convict) despite the evidence. For that reason, the only 
examples of documented jury nullification are with very homogeneous juries 
where it is socially acceptable to disregard the law. Those situations were 
and continue to be rare but they do happen.﻿
comments.author: Victor de Meireles

If they say not guilty, the guy doesn't get punished, 
If they say he is guilty, he gets punished, 
there is no third option " he did it, but we think he shouldn't be punished

comments.author: MichaelKingsfordGray

comments.text:
I'd like to point out to you, CGP Grey, if you ever read this.
To insinuate that an anarchist would be condone violence and hatred is 
simply offensive.

We do not hate nor do we commit acts of violence, we Anarchists simply 
believe in the right of self rule and Common Law.

Should a person be punished for murder? Yes.
Should a person be punished for Fraud? Yes.
Should a person be punished for Theft? Yes.

Should a person be punished for taking drugs? No. This action effects the 
person taking the drugs, no one else, you could argue there is an emotional 
pain on the family member, but the person is not putting another's life in 
danger, only their own. That is punishment enough.
Should a person be punished for being homeless? No, why should a man be put 
in jail, simply because he has no place to sleep?
Should a person be punished for wishing to live off the grid and become 
self-sustainable? No, so many Self-Sustaining Communities are being ravaged 
by Court Ordered Police, for the simple crime of not contributing OR taking 
away from the economy, they grow their own food, filter their own water 
(which is a public resource), heat their own homes and make their own 
electricity. Apparently that's against the law.

We Anarchists, CGP Grey, have but one agenda, for each man and woman on 
this Earth, to have the right to be free of taxes, free of the city and 
free of unfair rule, such as the laws I stated above.
We do not condone violence, fraud or theft and we strictly follow Common 
Law, you may know it as "The Law of the Land".﻿
comments.author: MrKhronicz

comments.text:
I would suggest Siberia, there are people there who have moved there many 
years ago to escape Stalin. I don't know how it is in your country, but in

comments.author: Officialhelpkenet

comments.text:
+PokemonTom09 In an Anarchistic society, we look after ourselves and each 
other, we punish people as a community for their crimes, I don't recommend 
Anarchy as a Global Scale reform on Government, I would simply like the 
choice, to find some land in the middle of nowhere and start a society 
where I would allow like minded people a home, it's for people who would 
rather be away from the surveillance world, away from the traffic, from the 
buss and tussle of modern work.

We would build our own houses, power ourselves, grow our own food and raise 
our own animals and NOT have to pay taxes to a Government that spends it on 
weapons.

I seriously don't think it's a crime, to want to live as a free man, but 
such settlements are being raided across the nations, Government doesn't 
like it when people go off the grid and become completely self sufficient, 
they can't make money off of us that way.

But seriously, we've got a lot of free land in the developed world, land 
that is at least 100 miles from anything.
In short, Anarchism is not a viable solution to the current state of our 
worlds Governments, but allowed on small scale such as new settlements, is 
much more beneficial to those settlements to grow and prosper and will 
provide an alternative to a lot of us who struggle to cope with the world 
being as chaotic as it currently is.

comments.text:
+MrKhronicz One thing that very few anarchists I've talked to about this 
have been able to answer: if there's no government, then who is enforcing 
these laws? In fact, who is coming up with them in the first place? If your 
answer is an independent police force, then what is preventing these people 
from creating laws for their own self interest? And if your answer is that 
the laws are voted upon, then who is organizing this democracy?

Also, one last thing: anarchists often call anarchy "controlled chaos," but 
those two words are literally antonyms.

comments.text:
+MrKhronicz It is very much in our human nature to follow someone with

I do agree that anarchy is incorrectly labeled as negative or violent, 
though. That is a strongly misinformed prejudice. It's a beautiful dream 
with very positive beliefs. It's just unfortunate that on the average, 
humans couldn't exist in such a format. It works in smaller communes, and 
has been successfully trialed as such. However, every trial eventually 
broke down thanks to some troubling niggles of human nature.

comments.text:

human nature to feel safe and modern society has made us believe that in 
order to be safe, we need leaders. It's simple conditioning. We are 
constantly told, "Oh look at this fucked up war-torn place, they don't have 
a Government and they are all fucked", but the average human doesn't 
realise that correlation doesn't equal causation.

Still, the point stands, I find it rather offensive to be labelled in any 
way as a negative force in the world, for believing in Anarchaic Principles.

though. Let's break that word down. U, from the greek word οὐ ("not") and 
topia from the Greek word τόπος ("place"), utopia literally means "not a 
place."
comments.author: Anonymous User

comments.text:
To help understand, break down the word Anarchy.

An, from the Greek Prefix, to be without.
Archon, from the Greek Noun, Rulers/Leaders.

Anarchy literally means "To Be Without Leaders"

comments.text:
+SomeDudeOnline You're right. This is why I don't really like this video. 
He suggests it it a "third option". It isn't, it's just a different way of

comments.author: James Samson

comments.text:
+James Samson Okay, so basically, jury nullification is simply the 
description of events that may take place whether or not the jury knows 
that it's called jury nullification?

It seems like everyone knows that a jury can convict with no evidence or 
not convict with mountains of evidence, so why is jury nullification some 
secret thing?
comments.author: SomeDudeOnline

comments.text:
+SomeDudeOnline Jury nullification is not returning a guilty verdict but no 
sentence. It is this: the right of the jury to give a guilty or not guilty 
verdict despite what the law or evidence points to. It might make better 
sense in an example. Imagine a legal system that makes abortion a crime. 
Kirsten is tried for aborting her child. The judge and lawyers advise the 
jury that to return a guilty verdict the law states that there must be 
clear evidence of an intentional abortion. Medical records prove that 
Kirsten had an abortion. The judge advises the jury the law has been 
broken. BUT the jury choose to return a not guilty verdict because although 
the law has been broken, they do not believe in sending people to jail who 
have had an abortion. That is jury nullification.
comments.author: James Samson
